newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: PolyGram may face protracted woes -analysts.
newsitem.headline: PolyGram may face protracted woes -analysts.

text.p: Analysts said on Wednesday that the music industry could be set for a protracted period of stagnation, which could mean music and movies group PolyGram needs to restructure further to improve earnings.
"PolyGram needs to reduce costs further to show a reasonable growth of say six or seven percent in earnings," said analyst Rene Verhoef of NibStrating after PolyGram issued a profit warning for 1996.
PolyGram's 1995 net profit grew only marginally to 741 million guilders ($433.3 million) from 738 million as a result of slack pop music sales in the important second half of the year.

And on Wednesday PolyGram -- 75 percent owned by Philips Electronics NV -- warned that full-year 1996 operating results would be flat or slightly down on 1995, adding that it would take a one-time restructuring charge of $90 million.

"I do not see the the stagnation as temporary, as PolyGram would have us believe," said Verhoef. The high growth rates of the past were over as consumers had finished replacing their LPs with CDs, he said.
"Margins in the industry are also under pressure as department stores want to purchase music more cheaply," he said, adding that the malaise could continue for several more years.
"The crucial thing is, will the market pick up?" said Joost van Beek of Van Meer James Capel, who said he was less pessimistic for the slightly longer term.
Van Beek foresaw PolyGram's earnings per share dropping to around 4.00 guilders in 1996 from 4.12 guilders in 1995. "But, in 1997 the figure could rise to 4.50 again," he said.
In the first half of 1996 PolyGram's net profit grew one percent to 272 million guilders, a slightly better result than most analysts' low-pitched expectations.
But PolyGram shares fell over seven percent to 78.60 guilders following the company's profit warning today.
Van Beek said PolyGram's movie business, still in the red at the moment, could break even at the operating level in 1997.

"The movie business is showing a strong increase (in volume)," said Verhoef, adding this sector counted for just about 10 percent of PolyGram's turnover at the moment but could eventually increase to about 25 percent of the total.
Van Beek said he saw no reason to change his forecast for tomorrow's third quarter earnings from Philips.
"My Philips forecast was already low," he said, adding he expected a 230 million guilder profit from normal operations, excluding extraordinary charges likely to be taken by Philips.
Analysts expect Philips' third-quarter net profit from ordinary operations to drop to 240-360 million guilders, far below the equivalent 1995 figure of 539 million guilders.
